title: Understanding Temporal Query Dynamics
segmentation: I'm Krista Sabori and this is work I did with Onaga Carney, Jaime Teevan, and Sue Dumais.
Went on ago was with us last summer for an internship an I'm going to talk about understanding query temporal query dynamics.
So the motivation behind this work is that we know that the web an web search is strongly influenced by time.
So we see that the popularity of queries really changes overtime queries themselves change overtime.
Some queries just appear.
We know that there's a very long tail, 50% of queries are new every day, but also the existing queries.
Really, the intent can change overtime.
The document content changes overtime, so pages are created, pages destroyed, but existing pages.
Actually, their content changes dynamically overtime and then also the intent behind queries.
What's really relevant to the user about a particular query.
I can change overtime and so these changes overtime are really the focus of.
This work?
So in particular, we can look at changes in query popularity.
In conjunction with changes in document content and what we want to know is, can we use these changes and identify a correlation with the change in query intent?
So as Harry Sean mentioned this morning, we're very interested in understanding the intent behind the query, not just the keywords anymore.
We need to move to the next phase of search.
So the takeaway of this talk, and this doesn't mean go to sleep now.

But the takeaway behind this talk is that we can look at changes in query popularity with changes in document content, and we can actually use this to determine there that there has been a change in query intent.
So I'm going to talk about these different aspects.
But before I get into the details of that, I want to start with just a concrete example.
So take the query March Madnes now March madness.
If you're from the United States or maybe elsewhere, you really like basketball, you know that this is a basketball tournament among college teams that occurs in the spring.
And again, it's college teams, so this is actually all teams that are part of the N CAA which is the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

But obviously NCA also has other teams in other sports among colleges and other tournaments that go on throughout the year, so the page for N caawhichisnca.com becomes relevant during the basketball tournament.
'cause that's when it really starts talking about the scores.
The teams who's in it, who's out, but it's really not relevant before after.
And you can see this with these snapshots.
So here we have a snapshot of nca.com before the tournament actually starts and you can see that that's really skiing season.
It's January, February.
We want to know who the greatest college skier is, but they're not talking about basketball.
But during the tournament you can see that there really highlighting the March Madness basketball tournament.
You can see they have an on-demand link.
You can watch it.
You can buy tickets.
You can find out.
Actually, even on the right on the right here we have a little scoreboard of which teams are in it, what the current their points are, and then finally after the tournament, we've moved on to Gulf.
Here we have a USC player and we've already gone to the golf championships.
There's no information about basketball here anymore, unless you were to know that final Four.
Is the final round of March Madness and here you can get tickets for next year, but that's really the only link and it's not really that relevant in May to get tickets for March next year.
On the other hand, Mahalo is kind of like a Wikipedia encyclopedia site, and their March Madness page is really always about March Madness.

So before, during and after the tournament, it looks like this, so there might be a little bit of content change, but it's always about March Madness, and you can always go here to find out what March Madness is.
So in our study, what we did is we took 100 temporal queries and we hand selected these queries and then we hand selected 20 documents for each of these queries.
So we have 2000 documents total in our study and how we selected these queries was we took.

We looked at the query popularity among the query logs from Bing for 2009 and we chose queries that spiked during this time period, which for us is the end of March to end of May is when we did this study during last year an queries that spike during that time period were things like.
April Fools tax extension.
Since there's a tax stating that time period in the US.
We also looked at change in relevant results, so queries with high click entropy during that time period last year included things like Miss USA Easter Baskets.
Then we selected a subset of queries for these hundred temporal queries related to scheduled upcoming events for 2010 that includes, like the iPod, was going to be released.
Crystal Bowersox was a very popular American Idol contestant and then queries that we anticipated to be likely to have breaking news, something like.
Earthquake we know that there's typically an earthquake every couple of months.
There might be one during this time period, so we selected Earthquake, and Lady Gaga tends to be in the news quite a bit lately, so she was likely to do something crazy during our study time period.
So we selected 100 temporal queries in this manner.
And then the corresponding documents.
And again, this is from the end of May end of March to the end of May, and we collected data regarding the queries.
So we got the daily query frequency.
We collected data about the document, the number of clicks for the queries daily.
Also the rank of those documents for those queries.
And then we also crawled the document content daily.
And then we looked out.
Also gathered query intent and here we gathered that by getting human judgments.
Weekly for these query URL pairs.
So let's first look at changes in query popularity.

So here we used the method of just looking at normalized query frequency overtime, and what we did is we characterized these curves or this query frequency for these queries into four different characterizations.
We looked at the number of spikes, the periodicity, the shape, and then also the trend.
Is it becoming more or less popular overtime?
And again, the time is this two month period that we're looking at.
So let's take an example and in the next set of slides it's always going to be date on the X axis versus query popularity on the Y axis.
So here again we have March Madness, our favorite query for this session and what we have is you can see that during the tournament it's quite popular.
People want to see which teams are announced here who's winning, but then after the tournament it becomes less popular.
So we call this a downward trend in popularity and we can see that there are multiple spikes.
Not periodic, we say Castle because it rises and then stays consistently popular for more than just a day for example.
Take the query dancing with the stars.
Well, this is actually periodic.
This is a weekly show.
It's actually twice a week.

The competition, followed by the results show and you can see that people really want to know who won, who won last night, who got kicked off and they're doing this every week fairly consistently as that TV shows aired.
As you can see, it's periodic.
Take the query MLB.
This is Major League Baseball during our study time period, it's showing an upward trend upward trend from when it's preseason.
They're just, you know, they're in practice and then all of a sudden all the games are starting.
It's really during the season and you can see people are.
There's kind of multiple spikes here, but for the most part they're looking at which teams are playing, where they're playing, and so forth, and so it's a general upward trend.
And then we have Miley Cyrus.
Well, she released a music video during our time period, so you can see that there is really one big spike everyone wants to see it.
It's a wedge.
What we call a wedge shape.
And then Earthquake is what we call a write sale when it happens, no one knew it was going to happen, so it really spikes and then people slowly become less interested.
And in this case it was a earthquake in Mexico.
And then we also have a corresponding left sale here.
This is the query tax extension as we get close to tax day.
The the trend is to look how do I file my taxes?
Can I get an extension and then it passes so people don't really care anymore until this time next?
So what we find with query popularity when we look at these when we characterize the queries in this way, we find that most of the queries in our study these hundred queries have one or more spikes.
They're mostly not periodic, they do.
Most of them have a wedge shape, and they do show some temporal trend upward downward trend.
So now let's take a look at changes in document content and the methods we look used to look at document content changes.
We crawl the documents daily and then we look at a query dependent Anna query independent measure.
So query dependent.
We simply look at the term frequency of the query words on the page.

Overtime again we have this daily crawl and then for a query independent measure of change we use the dice coefficient which takes the words from one day and looks at the overlap with the words from another day.
And this has been a measure used in the literature previously as well.
So let's look at our favorite March Madness example again in this pale green is the mahalo.

Mahalo term frequency, so this is date versus the log of the term frequency of March Madness, which is our query in pinkisnca.com and what you can see is that during the tournamentnca.com is really having quite a bit of change.
Quite a bit of a change in the content related to March Madness in terms of TF, but really, mahalo is staying quite static over the whole period an after the tournament.
Both of them are quite static.
And So what we find with the document content change is 61% of the pages in our study show a query related term frequency based change.

An 95% of pages changed by less than 15% in terms of the dice measure and we also find that periodic and multiple spike queries are more likely to have content changed documents than a periodic or single or no spike queries.

And that actually kind of makes sense if you think about the periodic queries like dancing with the stars, American Idol, we would expect that those those the content of those pages are changing because people are really looking for who the latest winners are who got kicked off, and so forth.
And with multiple spikes, think about someone like Miley Cyrus, Rihanna.
If it's spiking multiple times, they probably did something different in the news or they released a music video.
Or they wore the meat dress or something like.
But so you're really looking for different content.
And finally, let's look at changes in query intent.
So for query intent we looked at two measures of intent change.

One is explicit with human relevance judgments, so we had our query oral pairs judged weekly by human judges, expert human judges, and then we also looked at a user behavior measure, which is to look at the entropy of the clicked results.
Which the formula is given here.
And again we look at the entropy of the clicked results over the whole time period over this two month time.
Ram.
And So what we see?
So this is for the query again March Madness.
And at the bottom we're graphing the date versus the human relevance judgment, and the judgments are between zero and four.
This is fairly typical, and web search judgments.
So what we have?
Is on the left.
These dates are for the time period that is during the tournament itself, so you're looking for scores you're probably interested in schedules which teams are playing and so on.
And in that case you can see that the highest rated content of the highest rated results pages are NCA and CBS Sports.
These pages are really changing in content.
They're showing you the latest teams.
The latest scores are really more breaking news kind of items about sports, in particular about basketball.
And then the next relevant document is Mahalo, and also a subpage of nca.com, that kind of shows where you can watch different things, so there are little less relevant.
They're still relevant, but they're not necessarily addressing the intent at this time.
And then finally we have a page from 2008 that's really irrelevant at this time.
People are really interested in the scores and schedules from 2010.

And what you'll see is that after when we're looking more for general info planning for next year, the relevance actually changes, so you can see that the most relevant among this set is mahalo, and they really stay somewhat consistent in terms of the relevance overtime, but you can see also that these pink and red, the NCA and CBS Sports, has really become less relevant.
There are no longer showing things about basketball at this time.
They're probably showing things about golf as we.
Saw earlier.
And then the 2008 page basically stays irrelevant, so you can see that there's definitely been a shift in intent before people were very interested in scores and schedules.
After people are interested more in general info planning definition of March Madness.
So what we find in terms of measuring query intent in terms of user behavior and click entropy.
So we just looked at how the correlation with human judgments.
Now we're looking at click entropy, we find that it's correlated with oops.
I'm sorry with the number of spikes, so if the query popularity curve is exhibiting one spike, we find that that has lower click entropy significantly lower than if you had multiple spikes.
Inquiry popularity for shape.
We find that sale queries like taxes online PGA Tour has significantly lower click entropy than a wedge shape query, which would be something like Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart.
Wedge people find out, Oh my gosh, they might have gotten married.
Everyone wants to look so it's a different different shape and much less.
Click entropy here.
People might be interested in looking at all of the tabloids related to that and then for trend, we find that a downward trend has significantly lower click entropy.
Then a flat trend or a flat trend might be a query like Microsoft update.

So in summary, we find that changes in query popularity and document content are definitely related to changes in query intent, and we can use these signs to understand changes in query and intent or identify changes in query intent.
And specifically, we find that the number of spikes in the characterization, the shape of the curve, the query popularity curve and also the trend in query popularity.
If we look at that in conjunction with the content change on the pages, we find that this is correlated with a change in click entropy.
Which is a signal of query intent, and similarly we find that the periodicity when we look at that in conjunction with the change in content measured by Dyson term frequency.
We also find that this is correlated with the change in human relevance judgments, which is also a signal of query intent change.
So this is interesting because we can use these understandings of query intent change by looking at changes in document content changes in query popularity.
We can use that to actually change the web search for temporal queries.
In particular, we could look at changing the captions.
We could identify in the caption If we know the query, March Madness, intense changing, we could bring into the caption The latest scores, the latest teams, and so on.
Or we could actually change the ranking.
You know, during the tournament, mahalo maybe is ranked lower.
After the tournament we rank mahalo higher for example, and we can also just change the results display.
In general we saw this morning actors queries have special results displays.
We can consider different temporal dynamics, different types of temporal queries could have different types of displays depending on the change in query intent of the changing user user intent.
And we also find that the patterns of query intent there's there's different patterns of query intent change.
In particular, we have kind of a zoom zoom change, which is like March Madness.
It starts general, then we become more specific looking at teams and scores, and then it goes general again.
People are less interested, they just want general information.
There can be a shift.
Take the opening day of baseball that definitely people want the teams all of that.
And then if you live in Seattle, the opening day of boating season is big.
So in the end of May, all of a sudden you want to find out where when the opening day of boating season is, so that intent definitely changed entirely and it shifted.

And then finally, there's more of a static query intent change that it really actually has the same intent throughout the year, but the popularity is just changing overtime, so people saying querying Easter ideas in December really are looking for the same thing.
They're going to look for in April.
It's just less likely that they're going to query that.
In December.
